newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's Empress Michiko in hospital with fever.
newsitem.headline: Japan's Empress Michiko in hospital with fever.

text.p: Empress Michiko was admitted to hospital late on Thursday suffering a high fever and a headache, Japan's Imperial Household Agency said.
Court doctors diagnosed two days ago that the 62-year-old empress had herpes zoster, a form of a virus infection that causes rashes along the nervous system.
Michiko complained of a severe headache and high fever late on Thursday afternoon after attending an awards ceremony in Tokyo, the agency said.

"The symptoms of herpes zoster were receding, but we decided to hospitalise her highness to avoid the possibility of her developing meningitis," court doctor Tatsuo Ikenaga told reporters late on Thursday.
Government spokesman Seiroku Kajiyama told a news conference on Friday that Michiko's condition appeared stable and the empress was heading for recovery.
"We received an unofficial call (from the Household Agency) that her highness's condition has stabilised, with her headache better and fever lower," Kajiyama said.
Court doctors said Michiko's illness was probably due to fatigue from a two-week trip to South America in late May, when she accompanied Emperor Akihito.
Akihito and their daughter Princess Nori, 28, visited Michiko at the hospital on Friday morning, and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto expressed concern.

"I was worried because she wore a bandage on her arm at a tea party (on Wednesday)," Hashimoto told reporters. "Members of the imperial family work too hard fulfilling public duties. She has a headache so it's best she follows her doctors' advice."
The agency cancelled Michiko's official duties, including a planned meeting on Friday with visiting Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini.
The empress collapsed on her 59th birthday in 1993 and lost her power of speech for nearly seven months.
